entry.title: Literally this and that
entry.content:
Its been over a month since I last posted. I am not going to start all over again with what kept me busy. Although this post is about catching up with the last 1 and a half month.

I have been reading, like A LOT recently. I am on my 7th book already in this year, and hoping to achieve the targeted 50 at any cost. The OCDs in me keep kicking me to get closer to the number with each passing day. Results... I have been dying to read Vikram Seths The Rivered Earth, but I cant.. Even when I have the book sitting in my bookshelf, reason being the book is extremely thick and I dont want to miss my target by starting up with a heavy book. I am keeping it for the later part of the year when I am a bit closer of reaching 50.  I wont mind if this doesnt make any sense to yall.

March has been a bit tough to begin with. I lost a dear friend of mine this month. I dont know whether close would be appropriate here as we had hardly been in touch since past 2-3 years. This guy was from university, and we (The guy, my best friend, and me) shared a really close bond back then. Once we graduated and moved to new pastures, we both (best friend and I) lost contact with him. I did try to get back in touch over the years, but not mention worthy efforts. I know theres nothing we could have done but now when hes gone, we end up wishing having stayed in touch.

Our friend lost his battle against Hepatitis A. I hardly knew anything about the disease before knowing about him. Upon checking online, I was shocked of seeing the hepatitis A rates in India and other developing nations as compared to States, Australia, England. Apparently, the developed countries havent even issued mandatory vaccines for the disease reason being there strong infrastructure. Also, earlier I was one of those who used to mock people visiting India and getting their vaccines beforehand. I was like, Yea, right! You were born and brought up there, and now you want to be vaccinated first before visiting the place. I know I was vaccinated for hepatitis A when I was a kid (once vaccined is good for at least 25 years) but what I am wondering is how much are we aware about the disease? I, being an educated person, didnt know a thing about it. And sadly, many of the people dont.

The other half part of the post is going to be a whiny one. Now that we are two years into our wedding, our families (both husbands and mine) are after our lives for a baby which just is bizarre! They have been emotionally blackmailing us, giving us ultimatums, telling us that we are being irresponsible, and even asking us to fear from god (as he might change his mind and wont give us a child at all later when we want it). Its not that we dont want a kid; its that we dont want a kid anytime soon which apparently doesnt make any sense for them. And couples around us, getting married after us, have started having babies are of no respite really. Its not that I judge their decision but I can see them rolling their eyes on us! Will you just give us a break already!! I wish I could find a way out to make our families understand and respect our decisions.

Lastly, the book update Since I last posted, I have finished reading Since I dont have you by Louise Candlish, Us by David Nicholls, Inferno by Dan Brown and A diary of a Young Girl Anne Frank. The first two are fine for one time read, but I wouldnt recommend them, and I didnt write anything about A diary of a Young Girl because it doesnt need any recommendations. Its a masterpiece. Next on the list visit Anne Franks Museum in Amsterdam. I am currently reading, Angels and Demons by Dan Brown (one of the 4 books from Robert Langdon series). I have reached a conclusion I am a sucker when it comes to thriller and adventurous books. Obsessed with Robert Langdon!!

Thats what was going on. Now that I have written it down and caught up with the date, my OCDs have calmed down.

Till later,
Sameera

entry.title: In Love with..
entry.content:
So, I am finished reading two books after The Lowland. I wanted to mention the first one as soon as it was done, but because the other one was the series of it, I thought of better wait for it. I have just completed the Cormoran Strike series, The Cuckoos Calling and The Silkworm, two books written by Robert Galbraith (J.K. Rowling). If I were to write the review in one sentence, it would be Drop everything, and go read these books!! These books are brilliantly written, well woven, and I was hooked till the last word.
Image Source - Google

Cormoran Strike series is a thriller mystery, based in London. It has two central characters, Cormoran Strike(the detective) and Robin (the assistant). I have been a JK Rowlingfan ever since Harry Potter happened. I admire her for opting for the pseudo name for these books. Her writing style is simple yet gripping. I would highly recommend these books to anyone who fancies reading something light and engaging. Good news is Rowling would be coming up with 5 more books in this series!! *Happy dance* 


P.S. I am done with three books out of 50 this year! Currently reading - Since I Don't Have You by Louise Candlish.

entry.title: Lowland - Hit or Miss?
entry.content:
First things first! I started this book in 2014 and finished in 2015, so I'm confused whether to add it in the list of 50 or not. I might keep it on hold. Just in case I am not able to reach the goal of 50, I'll add it in this year's reads. Fair enough? Now coming back to the book. Lowland is written by Jhumpa Lahiri, famous from the 'Interpreter of Maladies'. I haven't read any of her work before, so didn't have much of an expectation.

                             

The Lowland is set up in West Bengal, after independence, then Calcutta. It is a story of two brothers who live for each other, the elder one being an introvert and younger one an extrovert. I wouldn't reveal the plot here so summing up it,s their journey from being best friends to choosing different paths in life to connecting in a way they would've never imagined. It involves the story of the women in their life - mother, wife, daughter. 

I am reluctant to recommend this book, as I found myself loosing connection with the characters midway through it. While the starting and end of the book are quite interesting, I found myself lost in the book. At times I wanted to skip the journey of Gauri (the wife) because of lack of connection, And on the other hand I wanted a better ending. Overall, I wasn't satisfied as a reader. 

That's that. Currently I am reading The Cuckoo's Calling. I have to say that I wasn't keen to start this one, but I am hooked. Can't wait to finish it! 

How's winter treating everyone? London is behaving rather quite nice, and we are hoping it stays the same. I have already started planning travel for this year, and we can expect some beautiful destinations up on the blog this year!! 

Have a lovely weekend everyone. 

*image courtesy: Google*

entry.title: Happy New Year
entry.content:
Happy New Year everyone!

Hope everyone out there had a fabulous new years eve!!

Image Source - Google

Talking about me, we had a quite one at home. Him went ill on 31st, and we decided to tuck in bed and watch fireworks at home. We went for London Eye fireworks last year, and had no plans to revisit the chaos this year, hence watching fireworks on TV seemed like a better option. I cant say enough of this I have no idea where did 2014 just go by! It seems like yesterday. Its 6 days into the New Year, and I dont find it any different from the earlier one honestly. New Year comes with the whole baggage of deciding upon the resolutions, and we (Him and I) are no exceptions. Each year we decide on some small targets, which we are hopeful to stick on. In 27 new years of my life, I have realised that I cannot accomplish heavy resolution goals, so since last few years I have started to come up with small goals which are realistic and achievable.

Last year, I posted my resolutions, and its that time of the year again. Posting them on the blog gives me motivation to stick to them and put (a tad bit) effort to complete them. I am not going to list all of them here, but naming a few:

  • This year, again, I will survive 31 days without sugar. I started this one last year, by getting motivated from Tanvi (from Tanvii.com). This does not include natural sugar from fruits, etc. this one is relatively easy for me, considering I don not have a sweet tooth. I do not crave cakes, chocolates, ice creams, desserts, almost ever.
  • I have also committed to myself, to read at least 50 books this year. I am an avid reader, so I will (hopefully) achieve this one as well.
  • I will volunteer at charities, at least once in two months. As I have mentioned a lot of times here, I work with a charity organisation, and since the time I have joined here, I have realised how much helpful it can be for a charity to get a helping hand. Added bonus it feels great!
  • Lastly, I will take blogging more seriously. On an average, I have posted almost two posts per month last year and that IS disappointing. Among the lot, this one is the most challenging for me because of my procrastination. There are times when I have a post ready in my head, but the lack of will to go and type, keeps me at bay. Hopefully, not this year!


P.S. I am already finished with one book Lowland, review will be up soon.
Ciao!

entry.title: Food Talk - Choco Lava Cake
entry.content:
Christmas is just two days away!!! I can't convince myself that Christmas is already here. I have mentioned on the blog at least a billion times that I love this time of year in London. Him's and mine offices have closed for 10 days, and we are all tucked in, with a whole list of Christmas movies to watch and lots of food to binge on! I thought I should share this quick recipe of making Choco lava cake. This one is ideal to eat any time of the year, but I love it especially during winter holidays. 




Ingredients
Baking Chocolate I took around 4 pieces
Butter 1/2 cup
Eggs 2
Sugar 1/3 cup
All-purpose Flour 1/4 cup 

Recipe 
1. Preheat the oven at 180 C. Melt the chocolate, and add butter to it. Mix thoroughly till butter dissolves completely in the chocolate. 
2. In a different bowl, beat eggs and sugar for around 4-5 minutes. Add the butter-chocolate mixture to the egg-sugar bowl. Finally add the all-purpose flour to it.
3. Apply a thin layer of butter inside the cup/ small porcelain bowl, and pour the mixture till it's 3/4 full.
4. Butter bottom and sides of ramekins (small glass/porcelain bowls) and pour in mixture until 3/4 way full.
5. Keep the bowls in oven for 10-15 minutes. I usually check after 10 minutes by poking a toothpick in it, as we prefer molten chocolate inside. 

That is it!!! I haven't tried making it in microwave, but I am pretty sure results would be the same. Keep it in microwave for a bit longer, and poke a fork or toothpick to check. ;)

entry.title: Summing Up Past Two Months
entry.content:
Starting off with the obligatory Sorry for being MIA

I last updated the blog in September and I was in India the complete October (AFTER ALMOST 2 YEARS). I had so much to write about that in the end I didnt document anything. This is one of those ideal cases of procrastination. Moving on, we were in India for a month celebrating the entire festive season. Now, I love India and I am one of those who bash the NRIs cribbing about Indian weather and cleanliness issues. I am so disappointed to say that I had turned into one of those this trip. I went ill the day we reached India, having fever as high as 104 degree C, and a sour throat for literally the WHOLE effing MONTH! I do not suffer from health issues (even minor) at all. Him has always been impressed by my immune system, as he cant count a single time in these two years of married life when I fell sick. So this fell as a hard one on him as well.


I have missed mentioning Karva Chauth, Diwali, and my birthday here. Skipping the former ones, Ill just write down about the birthday this year. I turned 27 this 3rd. Getting older doesn't scare me, and I have moved past the phase of being overexcited for the birthdays. We went on for our usual routines, off to work, and ended the day with watching a musical theatre and quite cozy dinner. I had been longing to watch WICKED since forever, I think may be since the day I first saw its poster when I moved to London. It was such a surreal experience, and I get it now why people prefer theatre performances over movies here. It is beyond explainable. I am a being fantasy buff, from Enchanted to Timothy Green, so there wasnt any chance I wont like this one. I would highly recommend watching this one.



While coming back from India, I have brought a whole lot of books with me because lets face it books are cheaper in India. I have stocked the entire pile to read for at least next 6 months. Currently reading Malalas biography I am Malala, and I am hooked! You know, how I mentioned in the review of A thousand Splendid Suns that I felt lucky while reading the book. Well, Malala tells you that indeed you are lucky and you cant be thankful enough! I know a thousand of people have already written about her but I have to! Her courage amazes me! Her father is the hero in her life, and how he has been there to guide her, and to be with her on the path father-daughter chose together!
Next on my agenda The Lowland by Jhumpa Lehri.

Another thing worth mentioning here is Hims latest addiction! Him has joined the ASOS Fan Club bandwagon. He has picked up this habit to place an order every alternate day on ASOS, try the clothes, choose the best ones and pack the others for return. Result I am the one visiting the collect+ store twice a week on my way to work! This better needs to stop.



Lastly, the chrismasifiedLondon!  London is at its best in December. Ive been lucky this year to enjoy festive season back home, and be back to London at the right time when the festivity had just begun! It couldnt have been prettier, and I feel lucky every time I look at those gorgeous street decorations in Covent Garden and Oxford Street.  

Will be back soon!

entry.title: Being an Introvert
entry.content:
I have always found myself pondering upon this thought Am I an Introvert or an Extrovert? I have been through a lot of phases, from being an introvert teenager to an extrovert young adult. Now, when I look back I find myself believing that when I was trying to be an extrovert I was just trying to fit-in. I am blessed with beautiful sets of friends and family. I am always left wondering, how do I always end up being friends with party people when I myself do not like being in crowd.

I have partied like crazy at times, not because I like dancing all night long, but because I enjoy the company of my friends. You know may be the before and after-time of head-banging on loud music. I am prone to anxiety. I have had anxiety attacks on tubes, crowdy events. I once started crying in the Delhi metro because I couldnt deal with the chaos.

I am not a conversation starter. I do not like to initiate a conversation, but once I am in it theres no looking back. I can sit by my own in a coffee shop for hours, with a company of a nice book. I am not a dancer - the person with two left feet. Instead of discussing with anyone, I prefer writing down my sentiments in a diary. I avoid responding yes to invitations where I dont know anyone.

I have covered the journey of trying to be an extrovert to preferring being an introvert. I enjoy the time with myself, and I prefer it over anyone elses company. Whats better than that? Innt? ;)


Moving on, this week we went for a 5K marathon Electrodash. Another experience noted down dancing with a bunch of crazy people. After the run, a DJ was organised for the runners, and the only things visible in the arena were the neon bracelets, headbands floating around. Few pictures from the event

entry.title: Book Review - Will Grayson, Will Grayson
entry.content:
Will Grayson, Will Grayson - A book completely different from John Green's other work. The three books are revolving around the teenage lives, still they manage to keep so called grownups hooked.  Call me insane, but I actually found one-sentence connection in all of the books. In WG, WG, Tiny mentions relationships can be predicted. You can point the plot on a graph. The other book by John Green, An Abundance of Katherines, is dedicated to the invention of this theorem. It might be weird, but I found it exciting to find such small relationships between the three books.

Image Source : Google

Where the fault in our stars is an intense love story, an abundance of Katherines is a journey of an intellectual guy, this book is all about friendship. This might be the spoiler alert, but till the few chapters you will not come to know that they are talking about two different Will Graysons. And you are utterly confused when they two meet.

How beautifully is the story woven! Commendable!

When I read about two Wills face to face, I thought this might be a suspense novel. But no, it is all about friendship. Two different Will Graysons with one common Tiny Copper, who is not so tiny. Tiny is not the supporting character, he is rather the life of this book. This book is a must read for those, yet again, love reading books. The intellectual ones might want to give it a skip.

This has been 4th book review in a row. I am getting too predictable, and also I dont think another review would be here anytime soon. Coz I have started with INFERNO by Dan Brown. And I am pretty sure it wont be as easy as the previous ones and would definitely take more time.


P.S. I am visiting India soon :D

link.title: Book Review - Will Grayson, Will Grayson

entry.title: Book Review - An Abundance of Katherines
entry.content:
Image source - Google

John Green!!

I am officially in love with his work. I am a FAN of John Green. After Shahid Kapoor, he is the man I want to meet at least once before dying! What a writer. I am sure not all of the people like his work, but a person like me who enjoys reading romantic/ light-hearted books once in a while; it is such a refreshing change. I read Fault in Our Stars' when it wasn't hyped enough as a movie, and recently I got hold of his rest of the two books An Abundance of Katherines and Will Grayson, Will Grayson. I am yet to read the latter one, but An Abundance of Katherines' has left me in spellbound with John Green's work. Upon thinking, I have concluded that I liked it more than the Fault in Our Stars. It leaves you with smile on your face.

It's a story of an extraordinarily intelligent 17 year old boy, Colin who calls himself a prodigy. He has been dumped by 19 Katherines till date, and after the latest break-up he thinks of inventing a formula which could depict that relationship beforehand. Dumper-dumpee relationship. The mathematical formulas do not restrain you from reading the book. I would hugely recommend this book to anyone who enjoys reading books. It's a refreshing change for regular readers, and a light book for occasional ones.

P.S. I have already started his third book Will Grayson, Will Grayson. If I like this one as well, I am getting a John Green tattoo. JK. *not

link.title: Book Review - An Abundance of Katherines

entry.title: Book Review | Gandhi - My Experiments with Truth
entry.content:
Look whose back.

So as I mentioned in my earlier post about the current book reading spree, I am so happy to tell y'all that it is still going on in a full swing (:

Image Source - Google

I have kept down another book today called 'An Abundance of Katherines', by John Green. Book review in another post because I finished Mahatma Gandhi's autobiography few weeks back, and it definitely deserves a blog post. I have to tell the truth, I am not a non-fiction kinda person and hence I did not buy this book. Rather if it would had been me, this book would have never reached my bookshelf. This book reached to me when one of my friends moved from London, and had to give away some of his books. Destiny? I am so happy that I picked this book from the shelf to read. It has SO MUCH to teach. Before writing down the review, I must say that I am not a very big fan of Gandhi's ideologies.  In India, everyone has a different viewpoint about Gandhi's ideologies and I wouldn't want to go into his political role and everything. Even the book has nothing to do with it. It has his journey from being a 7 years old to an adult.

It tells his views on his child marriage, about being in control of lust, about how he was one of like us. A normal person with usual routine, and an irk to be better and presentable than rest of the society. It takes you on his journey when he wanted to go to England to study further, with a wish to be superior. He admits being materialistic, and then discusses the path taken to achieve no attachment. At one point you can totally relate with him when he writes about the materialism within himself, and on the other hand when he mentions his efforts to get rid of it it forces you to think what are you exactly doing with your life.

He has written about everything - his experiments with diets. He was earlier one of us, typical Indians, eating for the tongue, and then gradually made it to eat to survive. How difficult would have that been? The will, the dedication, it makes you respect him. How he unintentionally jumped into the welfare of fellow people in South Africa, and in later in India. How his take on vegetarianism is completely different from Indians of older generation. He writes, he is a vegetarian not because of the religion beliefs and morals but because he felt non violence includes towards animals as well.

As he writes, ""If we are to be nonviolent, we must then not wish for anything on this earth which even the meanest or the lowest of human beings cannot have."

This book is a must read, for self awakening. For a different approach for life, for a stronger will that's inside there to do something for the society.

P.S. That's one heavy post. I went too much into it, didn't I? :D
The another book that I ll be reviewing shortly is on a lighter note. Thankfully.
Also, just in case anybody wants to know what did I start with after reading the book. I volunteered at my office, and went to distribute pamphlets regarding the free classes being organised for children with learning disability and from weaker sections of society. I know it's not that a big deal, but trust me it makes you feel good.

link.title: Book Review | Gandhi - My Experiments with Truth

entry.title: A letter to 16 years old me
entry.content:
Hi 16 years old me,

This is you writing for you 10 years into life. I want to tell you life is not at all bad, and you are doing well. As I look back and see how I used to be, I have smile on my face and that smile is because f you! You make me proud of myself. I want to tell you that you've done pretty well in life till now, and you are living each day with full zeal and excitement. Right now you must be struggling with 4 tuition classes per day, along with school, and feeling inferior in front of your classmates. I want to tell you stop thinking about yourself this way. You are no less than any of them, and youll never be. I, right here, am the proof. Today, when all of them are having kids and enjoying their social life by discussing TV serials, you have a full-time job, a loving husband, a house full of responsibilities, and adventurous activities each week.

Also, the preparations you are doing for all those entrance exams, theyll lead you nowhere. Youll end up at another PTU college, and would make some friends for lifetime. One more thing, 10 years from now, youll be in London working as a creative writer. Who would have thought of that? The crush you have on that guy from tuition, youll overcome it soon and will meet the love of your life in college. You had a love marriage, and as I write this its already been a year and a half into the wedding bliss! And stop thinking that mom dad dont let you live your life and are way too strict because after 10 years youll understand that it wasn't strictness, it was coaching to learn how to make right decisions. You definitely wouldn't want to turn into a stupid woman, would you?

I think I have disclosed enough of future for you. I want to tell you, stop feeling bad about yourself. You are doing everything right, and enjoying your teenage perfectly well. Theres no hurry to turn older. I am proud of the innocence you have, and I feel happy when I look back and see how wonderfully I lived those years. It is because of you, I live my life today without any guilt of making a wrong decision ever. Go and thank your parents for that.

26 years old me

P.S. I know it's not a usual post, and I had to think quite a lot before publishing it. But what the heck, this is my blog after all. Routine posts will resume over the weekend.

Anyone else has written a letter to their younger versions?

link.title: A letter to 16 years old me

entry.title: Book Talk - A Thousand Splendid Suns
entry.content:
Eeeh!!

It's officially not a month yet since this space was last updated. Can anyone see a happy dance? This month I started working with a lovely small charity organization, working for the young people. It's such an overwhelming experience to go there, and watch the kids learn. The major plus point is that they learn different art and culture activities, like theater, music recording, ballet, photography, Asian dance. You name it, and they have it. It has kept me busy for good.

Recently the book reading bug hit me again. Thank god for that. In last three months, I have read more than six books. Isn't that great? When I was in my teens, I used to write down the name of the book and author in my diary after reading it, along with small review. Of course, I wasn't aware of the blog culture at that time. So, it hit me today that I should update this space from now onwards with the synopsis of the latest book I have read. I am slowly going to update the blog with all the books read. Starting with the latest book I Have read - A thousand splendid suns !

Image Source - Google

Khaled Hosseini impressed me with his work in The Kite Runner. I am not proud of the fact that it took me so much time to get my hands on another of his master piece. Like the Kite Runner, A thousand splendid suns is also set in Afghanistan. It is beautifully written, hurt wrenching story of two women woven parallel to each other. You cannot refrain yourself from getting attached to these two - Mariam and Laila. Born and bought up in entirely different household how fate brings them together under the same roof. You feel sad for the, proud of them, and what not. The story moves from the rule of Soviets on Afghanistan, to Talibani dictatorship, to the US - Afghanistan war. How a two women are affected from the war as well as typical male dominance. You cannot help but feel privileged and fortunate to be born in a country where you had right to speak, to rebel, to the basic right like education. 
The book nook :) #momsaysthat
A Thousand Splendid Suns is an intense piece of fiction. Now, I cannot wait to grab 'And the mountains echoed' also written by Khalid Hosseini. Meanwhile, these days I am reading the autobiography of Mahatma Gandhi. I am not a fan of biographies or non fiction books. But this one has managed to keep me hooked. I will post a review as soon as I complete it. I am going to be here more often, so apologies in advance for the ones who have subscribed to the blog through email. Hopefully, you won't mind that ;)

entry.title: Travel Diaries - Barcelona
entry.content:
It's almost been a month since I last posted something on the blog. My bad! I had a planned trip in April, and thought of posting a post here after the trip. So, we traveled to Barcelona this month. I am in love with this city. The advancement and globalization has not overpowered the cultural essence of the city. The city is so warm and friendly that I am already waiting to visit it again. Him is a pro at planning trips, and I have hardly anything to worry about when it comes to traveling, right from getting printouts of the tickets, charging the camera batteries, to booking cab to airport. We also went to watch circus this weekend. Last I watched a circus was two years back in India which was not worth it. All the performers there looked tired and hardly interested in their acts. We actually left the circus within 20 minutes. I had been looking forward to watch a circus here to see the difference. And we thoroughly enjoyed the 2 hours act. The major plus point was that they didn't have any animal acts, and it was all based on the talent of performers. Deserves a brownie point, innit? Also while all were going crazy about 2 States on Facebook, Him declared that he is not interested in watching Chetan Bhagat's life based movie onscreen. entry.title: Food Talk - Mint Chutney
entry.content:
Another food post! *Yayy me* Although, any expert cook would laugh on my naivety in cooking department. Now this is the recipe of a simple chutney. I learnt this one from my mom, long years ago. I am sure I was around 12-13 years old, when I tried making this dish. My mom is a working lady, so she hardly ever had time to prepare chutneys and pickles for us. One day upon seeing mint, I stomped my feet in front of the vegetable vendor that I had to have chutney that day. Mum told me that she'll make it only if I ll help her clean the mint and coriander leaves. That was the first time ever I tried my hands on anything in kitchen. Of course, I just helped her in cleaning leaves and tasting afterwards.

After wedding. it has been a ritual at my home to prepare this chutney every Sunday. I just bottle it up on the weekend, and we enjoy it with most of our meals entire week.

Mint Chutney


Preparation time: 15 minutes
Cooking time: 5 minutes

Ingredients:
Mint - I usually get the pack from Asda, or similar store. You can get a bunch of mint leaves. Say around 100 gms
Coriander - Equal to the quantity of mint. Make sure that the quantity of coriander is not less than mint as it can turn the taste bitter.
Tamarind - A small portion. *Soaked in warm water for half an hour*
Salt - As per taste, or 2 small spoons
1 Onion
1 spring onion
1 green chilly. You can add more, if prefer spicy.
Cumin seeds - half tablespoon. *Roasted*
Dry mango powder - half tablespoon
Half lemon

Procedure:
1. Remove the leaves from the stems, and wash them twice or thrice in running water.
2. Cut onion and spring onion in broad pieces.
3. Add the leaves, onion, spring onion and tamarind water in grinder. Grind to smooth paste.
4. Add salt, cumin seeds, dry mango powder to the paste, and grind for few seconds again.
5. Now shift the chutney to a clean container, and add lemon juice.

That is it! Chutney ready. You might want to put it in a bowl or a jar, and keep it in fridge. Try consuming it within 5-6 days of preparation. If you want to keep it for longer duration, add some citric acid while adding salt, and all in step 4.

entry.title: Kids ain't easy boy!
entry.content:
This week has been extremely busy, and not the good busy. Usually, I am happy when while going to bed I do not know where did the entire day went by. But at times there are days which are extremely busy and still every hour is difficult to pass. This week came under the latter category. Last year during early summers, I came in touch with an amazing Indian family. A young early thirties couple with 2.5 years old kid. I am not at all good at handling kids but this little girl, lets call her munchkin, made her way in my arms. She didn't scare me at all. and I have been loving to spend every possible time with her since then. The friend of mine (mother of kid) was expecting at that time, and now they are a lovely family of four. In this year in London, I have found a super amazing friend in her. The kind of friend whom you can call at any time of the day without thinking twice.

This Tuesday, when I was on my way to swimming class, my friend called me for help. The little munchkin had cut her right hand's finger while the mum was busy in kitchen. And as my friend's husband couldn't attend the call due to some meeting, I was the only one who came in her mind. Munchkin, who otherwise is a happy kid, was crying miserably. The little kid's finger needed stitches and upon X ray we came to know that there was a minor fracture too. Hence, surgery was the option. These have been few of the toughest days  of my life. Seeing a kid cry inconsolably, and being helpless. We bought her home yesterday, after three days in hospital. Little kid was terribly scared, and didn't leave her dad's lap for a second. 

The entire incident made me think on several things. Upon seeing this happy kid, I used to think may be dealing with kids is not that bad. But it definitely is. I saw the parents crying on their helplessness. Mother saying again and again, "I went away just for a minute." These kids need undiverted attention. Him said to me once, "I don't know about myself but I am confident that you ain't ready."

I read somewhere once that a person makes lifelong friends by the age of 25, and I found the statement extremely true because all my friends whom I have been connected with since long are either from school or college. There are few ex work friends as well, but I haven't yet felt for them that way. You know, lifelong is a huge term! Anyhoo, I have now realized that this statement is not true. Friendship knows no age. The little Munchkin when called me Masi, and the friend who hugged me for being there. I knew, I loved them.

This post has no pictures. I had a planned post in my mind, but I had to write this one before this thinking mode finished. The planned one would be up on the weekend.

Till then,
Happy weekend.

entry.title: How much is too much?
entry.content:
I have a really good friend circle. You know the type of friends with whom you can spend n number of hours, talking about useless stuff. Yes, we pull each others leg but in a healthy way. You getting my point? But when you have such amazing groups of friends (with groups I mean college friends, ex work friends, etc.), how do you draw a line? For example, when some friend of mine tells me his problem, I do not give him advice till the time I am sure he needs one. Because most of the times, they just want to rant. And once the ranting is over, they are perfectly fine. I make sure to compliment them, but also ensure not to criticize them at any of their choice. It's their life after all, if they are happy with their choices who am I to give an opinion.

Some such friends do not follow the term vice versa. They will poke their nose in your personal matters, and would give you their unasked advice. Basically, they do not know the difference between pulling leg and making fun. They can't figure out how much is too much! I have struggled to come in terms with such kinda people. Because, I still considered them friends and found it hard to let them go. But in past few weeks, I have reached a point where I can firmly say that such people DO NOT need a space in your life. Their only motive is to spread negativity under the mask of humor.  It's better to cut them out instead of spending time on thinking about their *shitty* opinion.

Hmmff, that was some serious talk. In other news, I had this blog in mind for the complete last week. Only reason I couldn't update it was I wanted to post something with pictures. I mentioned in a post few days back that I have been wanting to learn photography. So apparently, the YouTube tutorials were not my cup of tea. I came across this amazing photography class on meetup headed by Chris Lawman, a wedding photographer. If interested you can join the group at Beginner Photography Classes. I have just got basic understanding of the features ISO, aperture, focal length, focal stops, etc., and need to start practicing now.

Leaving you with pictures from the class at Southbank.

entry.title: Food Talk - Butter Chicken
entry.content:
I am on a blogging spree nowadays, hope this enthusiasm persists forever. Now I am a vegetarian since forever. And I have always hated when people roll their eyes and say, "You are a Punjabi so how can you be a vegetarian?" I am answer less. I don't know what to tell them so they can SHUTUP. I am a vegetarian because of my personal choice. No one forced me to turn into one, and neither is it a religious bound. I don't feel like eating, hence I don't. Period.

Him has always been a non vegetarian, and since the day we got married he has been cooking all the meat by himself. Of course the lazy ass refrained from experimenting in the kitchen, so last year EVERY SINGLE SUNDAY he ate 'The grilled chicken with stir-fried veggies'. Finally I gave in, and told him that I'll cook chicken for him. I have cooked chicken for 4-5 times now, and although I haven't ever tasted it but I am going to trust Him on this as he said - It smells like my mom's kitchen in here. That's a compliment!

So, I thought of sharing the recipe here.

BUTTER CHICKEN (serves two)


Preparation time: 10 minutes
Cooking: 20 minutes
Ingredients

250 gms chicken (boneless)
Butter - 1 big tablespoon
paste of 6-7 cashew nuts (soaked in water overnight)
Whipping cream - 1 big spoon
Milk - 1 cup
Salt - according to your taste
1 finely chopped green chilly
Pinch of red chilly powder or paprika
half tablespoon turmeric powder
1 tablespoon dried fenugreek leaves
2 minced onions
4-5 minced garlic cloves
2 tomatoes pureed
A small piece of ginger
Garam Masala - half tablespoon
1 spring onion - chopped
Coriander leaves - for granishing

Procedure:

Melt the butter in the pan, and add onion and garlic to it. Add salt and fry till it turns light brown. Now add chilly powder, turmeric powder, and let it fry for a minute.

Add tomato puree, ginger, cashew nut paste, fenugreek leaves to the mixture, and fry it till the butter starts to bubble at the corners of the pan.

Add the chopped spring onion, chicken pieces, milk, garam masala, and cover the pan for 10 minutes. Keep the stove on sim, and stir occasionally in between.

Put the whipping cream, and stir for few minutes. I do not eat non veg, so I checked whether the chicken is cooked well  or not by applying pressure with the spoon.

Garnish it with finely chopped coriander leaves.

As simple as that (:

entry.title: Beauty Talk - Current Favorites
entry.content:
So, I thought of making better use of this space. Apart from my usual ramblings (which of course will continue), I thought that I should also share my current favorites here. This might help anyone looking for similar products. Hence from now onward, I will be regularly updating the blog with my current obsessions. This may be anything from a beauty product, apparel, or an eating joint I have lately discovered.

Today I am reviewing two of my current favorite products, in no particular order.



St. Ives Apricot Scrub

This scrub had been sitting on my desk since a while now, untill Tanvi (from Tanvii.com) reviewed it on her blog. Upon reading her review, I had to give it a try. And oh boy, was I impressed! Since a long time, I had been a regular user of FabIndia scrubs and as it was hard to find those here in London, so I bought St. Ives apricot scrub. I have to say, this one is much much better than the Fab India one. It has a very pleasant fragrance, not too strong. The texture of this product is quite creamy and has grainy apricot particles which are extremely gentle on the face. And this product works wonders. Each time I use this scrub, it leaves my face smooth and fresh.

This scrub has also received a heads up from 'Him', which trust me is a big thing!! He, for first, does not use any of these stuff. So when he mentioned the other day, "What is that tube in the bathroom? I like it." I knew I had to mention it here.

If you are looking for an effective and easy on pocket scrub, this one is made just for you!

Where to buy from:
I ordered this online from Asda.com. It is also available across different drugstores like Boots.com and Superdrug.

Floral Collection Magnolia Body Cream

To be honest, I bought this body cream from M&S without any expectations. It smelt very nice and was cheap, hence off it went to my basket. entry.title: To the Moon and Back
entry.content:
What does this phrase mean? I have some unresolved issues with the phrase "To the moon and back". I have seen people using this phrase when they have a splendid time. While, I want to use this phrase when at one moment I am the top of the world and on the other moment right on the floor -witnessing the highs and the lows, the way I did in these first 15 days of February.

February started on a high note. With the much awaited trip to Portugal and Paris, we also marked the first successful and happy year of our marriage. I think my first year of wedding was a piece of cake, with no major fights and no disappointments. Although, I have had my share of roller coaster ride in this year. The major one was being without a job for an year. This was tough, very tough! I haven't ever been without work since the day I completed my graduation. I did not ever think that job hunt would be this difficult here. It definitely hit my self confidence. 

The trip to Paris and Portugal was A.M.A.Z.I.N.G. Both the places are extremely different from each other, in terms of crowd, culture, heritage. While Lisbon was quite, Paris was fast paced. I loved Paris, but Lisbon had my heart for sure. I will visit you again, for sure.


Tower Belem, Lisbon
Sintra, Potugal

entry.title: Love for Sitcoms
entry.content:
I am in love with a number of TV series right now, right from Shameless, Cougar Town, How I met your Mother, to Game of Thorns, and Big Bang Theory. I remember when I first came to know about the concept of sitcoms. How I met your mother was the first ever series I watched, and fell in love with Barney's charm and Ted's hopeless romantic nature. It was in 2009, when I had plenty of time on my hands just after completing my engineering. After that I got busy in shaping my career, and didn't see any of the other series, though I watched each and every season of HIMYM as a loyal fan.


Now in 2013, I again had plenty of free time on my hands. After getting married, and relocating to London, and being unemployed for nearly an year, I saw many of the TV series which I am ashamed that I never saw before. Like FRIENDS!!! How could I ever miss that show. It is such a classic masterpiece. It should not be missed by anyone, whosoever. That is one show that I ll make my kids watch in their teens. With each episode, I loved it more.

In the past 1 year, I watched all the seasons of friends TWICE!! I started shameless, and big bang theory, and cougar town. The whole concept of television is completely different in India and western world. I do not know when would the time come, when we'll be proud of our television industry. Indian television saw a change in 90s, with the launch of all those basic saas bahu sagas, but ever since it has been stagnant (apart from few good reality shows here n there). Indian television will have to grow leaps and bounds to have a respectable place in the market.

Apart from watching the TV series, I have been trying my hands on different cuisines. I am not an excellent cook, nor have I ever tried my hands on anything difficult but being said that, I enjoy cooking. I get happy when my food is appreciated. London is getting chilly. It is still better than the February last year, when I came. I really hate the weather in February here.

Lastly, I have to update the layout of the blog. I have completely forgotten how to add widgets through the code, or may be Blogger has changed some settings. Now this definitely on my To-do list.

entry.title: First Post
entry.content:
So I had this resolution this year that I will blog once a week, no matter what. I posted a post in the first week, and then we had to move to another place. Hence, lost the internet connection. Finally after waiting for good 10 days, I have the internet back, and I am ready to work on my resolution. Apart from this, the resolutions that I had were:

1. I will brush my teeth before going to bed, no matter how I lazy or tired I am.
2. I will cut down my sugar intake.
3. I will become a pro at swimming.

And I am happy to announce, that so far I am working on all three of them - without fail!

The blog is for my usual ramblings, as I love to write.. I will be regular here, definitely this time!

entry.title: About Mom Says That
entry.content:
'Mom Says That' was created on a lazy winter evening.The blog is about bits and pieces that make me.


About Me - 

I relocated to London after getting married in 2013.

I was born and raised in India.

I love writing. I am also a professional IT writer.

I have recently discovered my love for swimming and traveling, in that particular order.

I enjoy cooking. Although, I cannot cook exotic dishes. I prefer making easy, tasty, and healthy meals.

I am a big movie buff, and a die hard DISNEY lover.

I do not like to initiate conversations, which is often misinterpreted as ego.

I am a Shahid Kapoor fan, ever since Ishq Vishq happened.

I find it hard to let go people in my life.

I have a huge candle fetish. Buy me a candle or a candle stand, whenever in doubt.

I cannot live without a job. I love working.

I prefer doing work myself, instead of seeking help.

I hate to ask favors.

entry.title: Hey Sameera. It was a nice read. All the best with...
entry.content:
Hey Sameera. It was a nice read. All the best with parenting.

And when you say "easier for second-time parents," I guess it's more scarier for second time parents because they know exactly what they are getting into...he he he.

I guess first time is less ruthless because most of the things are unexpected and new, and you learn by taking one step at a time. But if I and Anu would go for a second child, it will hit us all in one go. The pressure is more.

Anyway, keep writing. I hope you add a dedicated series about parenting. I'll be your loyal reader.

Happy Parenting!
